quoteFirst: Each division has its own crew, so that the men leaving New York are relieved at Syracuse by others, and these in turn at Cleveland. The New York crew go to work, as has been said, at 4 P.M., and if the train is on time at Syracuse, as it usually is, they arrive there at
quoteLast: , after thirteen and a half hours of as hard work as men are called upon to do. The same evening at 8.
title: The American Railway: Its Construction, Development, Management, and Appliances
author: Clarke, Thomas Curtis, 1827-1901; Cooley, Thomas McIntyre, 1824-1898 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: When he began to think it might be as well to return home, and to feel as if fifteen wolves were inside him fighting for their dinner, he was in some obscure and remote region of Chelsea, where the population was more crowded than aristocratic, and the ice abundant. Happening to cast his eyes to a clock in a baker's shop he saw that it wanted but
title: Oswald Cray: A Novel
author: Wood, Henry, Mrs., 1814-1887

quoteFirst: From this position to the enemy's redoubts it was about half a mile in a direct course westward, and from the advanced skirmish line to the same works some 400 yards. About 5:15 p.m. the various batteries of the Union forces opened fire upon the enemy's lines, but their guns did not reply for about ten minutes, when the cannonading became brisk on both sides, lasting until
quoteLast: ; the battery near the regiment sharing in it. Now it ceased suddenly on our side, and in its place were heard the ringing cheers of the soldiers as they rose, in full view of the reserves, from their trenches in the front and rushed towards the Confederate fortifications.
title: History of Company E of the Sixth Minnesota Regiment of Volunteer Infantry
author: Hill, A. J. (Alfred James), 1833-1895; Stees, Charles J.

quoteFirst: The counsel for the accused had no other defence than the point which I mentioned in my diary; but this he turned to account beyond all expectation. It appeared that the time when Miss Frick left the pawnbroker’s could be substantiated to the minute, by the circumstance that the pawnbroker on this occasion had looked at his watch and asked his clerk if the time was not
quoteLast: .  The clerk had then leant out of the window, looked at the clock in the church tower, and answered in the affirmative.
title: The Black Tortoise: Being the Strange Story of Old Frick's Diamond
author: Sparre, Christian, 1859-1940; Brækstad, Gertrude Hughes [Translator]

title: A Winter Amid the Ice, and Other Thrilling Stories
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: This morning the natives commenced by throwing stones at the men who went down for the water, but we did not see any method of resenting it, except by expressing our disapprobation in words, and at
quoteLast: we started on a north-north-west course, the natives followed for about a mile, and continued throwing stones at the party. The country passed over was generally grassy granite hills till 9.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: One company of the 9th Machine-Gun Battalion was attached to each infantry brigade, the remaining one and a company of the 104th Battalion being detailed to barrage certain points to cover the infantry advance, and then to form part of the divisional reserve.
